author: S Poorvaja
text:
After parts of roof packing rained down on students at a school in Pammal on Monday, the incident brings to focus the necessity for frequent checks to ensure school buildings are safe havens.

Following the Kumbakonam Fire Tragedy in 2004, the Supreme Court of India had given directions on safety and building specifications that had to be implemented across all schools in the state.

According to the direction, an inspection team consisting of experts — including a civil engineer, health and revenue officers, fire officer, local body official and education authorities — need to carry out inspections and assessment of infrastructural facilities in schools before the commencement of each academic year. The report should then be submitted to the district Chief Educational Officer concerned.

“However, this has not been done in many districts, which means that infrastructural irregularities often don’t go under the scanner,” said A. Narayanan, founder of Change India.

Mr. Narayanan had recently filed a petition in the High Court demanding the closure of nearly 746 private schools that had been functioning without permanent recognition and flouting norms with regard to safety and infrastructure.

“The education department should step up the process this year and conduct checks across all schools during the summer vacation to ensure that students study in a safe environment,” he said.

The Supreme Court Order also specifies that safety measures prescribed by the National Building Code of India 2005 are to be implemented by all government training schools, which also require teachers and other staff to be trained to handle emergencies.
title: ‘Regular checks needed’
